author: By Astead W. Herndon and Shane Goldmacher
title: They’ve Both ‘Won Every Race’ So Far, and Want a Win in New Hampshire
description: Elizabeth Warren would have liked more speaking time at the debate. Amy Klobuchar said she had a home-field advantage at an ice arena. Both spent the day after making the case that they’re the ones to defeat President Trump.
content: HANOVER, N.H. — There is some disagreement on whether the post-debate glow of Senator Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota should be called “Klomentum” or a “Klobucharge,” but whatever the terminology — she had it Saturday afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Laquan Smith: Fall 2020
description: See the looks from the Laquan Smith: Fall 2020 Collection.
content: See the looks from the Laquan Smith: Fall 2020 Collection.

title: The Winners of Our Fifth Annual Review Contest for High Schoolers
description: Of a record 2,300 entries, we selected nine winners, eight runners-up and 18 honorable mentions. Read the winning essays here.
content: A Garfield-inspired restaurant. Doc Martens. New York’s Penn Station. A Lizzo concert.

author: By Tim Herrera
title: 3 Simple Things You Can Do Today to Improve Your Finances
description: It’s easier than you think.
content: Welcome to the Smarter Living newsletter! Every Monday, S.L. editor Tim Herrera emails readers with tips and advice for living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Billy Porter’s Oscars Look Has Ties to Kensington Palace
description: How one room in a centuries-old palace found its way onto the red carpet.
content: By now, the actor Billy Porter has become as famous for theatrical red carpet looks as he is for his theatrical career. There was the refined black velvet tuxedo dress he wore to the 2019 Academy Awards, his golden sun god costume from the Met Gala later that year. And most recently, for the Grammys, he wore a meme-inspiring twinkling blue hat with an electric fringe curtain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sanam Yar
title: Beanie Feldstein’s Oscars Look
description: The star of “Booksmart” and “Lady Bird” got ready for the Oscars with tulle and a place for her inhaler.
content: “How many headbands do I have?” asked Beanie Feldstein, the star of “Booksmart,” who was standing in the elevator of a Miu Miu store in New York City recently. She was there for a fitting for the custom gown she would wear to the Oscars as a presenter, and after a pause she answered: “Easily over 50.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Besha Rodell
title: The D’Arenberg Cube Is a Zany, Adult Fun House
description: Chester Osborn designed the structure at his family’s 108-year-old winery, and he wants its restaurant to be the best in the world.
content: MCLAREN VALE, South Australia — The Cube rises from neatly tended rows of grapevines in the middle of the d’Arenberg winery like a meteorite from some faraway jagged dimension. Housing art galleries, a restaurant and a wine tasting room, the giant glass geometric structure is both impressive and confounding from the outside. That confusion only intensifies once you enter the five-story building, where you are greeted by a statue of an upended life-size cow, cradling a large vintage polygraph machine in its outstretched legs.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Wonderland at a Winery
description: Since its opening in 2017, the d’Arenberg Cube in McLaren Vale has attracted about 1,000 visitors each day, making it one of South Australia’s most popular tourist destinations.
content: Since its opening in 2017, the d’Arenberg Cube in McLaren Vale has attracted about 1,000 visitors each day, making it one of South Australia’s most popular tourist destinations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Barbara Marcolini
title: Thailand Mourns Mass Shooting Victims
description: A soldier killed dozens in a shooting rampage in Korat, Thailand.
content: A soldier killed dozens in a shooting rampage in Korat, Thailand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: ‘Losing Friends’ Over How She Covers the New Hampshire Primary
description: The podcaster Lauren Chooljian has irked some people in the state with “Stranglehold,” a close look at an all-important contest.
content: CONCORD, N.H. — The other day, Lauren Chooljian received a text from her father, a lifelong New Hampshire resident, that said: “You’re losing friends in nh.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Iowa Democrats Give Buttigieg the Most Delegates as Sanders Team Seeks Recanvass
description: Errors in the results have led The Times and others to refrain from calling the race, and the Sanders campaign manager said a partial recanvass of precincts could change the outcome.
content: DES MOINES — Nearly a full week after the Iowa caucuses, the state Democratic Party on Sunday released results indicating that Pete Buttigieg, the former mayor of South Bend, Ind., was the winner after it updated data from 55 precincts. But errors in the result tabulations have led several news organizations, including The New York Times, to refrain from calling the race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mariel Wamsley
title: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Homeland’ and ‘High Maintenance’
description: An acclaimed series airs its final season on Showtime. And a new series of New York vignettes is on HBO.
content: HOMELAND 9 p.m. on Showtime. Carried by Claire Danes as Carrie Mathison, a bipolar C.I.A. officer, and Mandy Patinkin as Saul Berenson, her mentor, this series begins its final run. When the show began in 2011, a decade after the Sept. 11 attacks, Carrie was investigating a POW-turned-al-Qaeda-agent, who later became her lover. In battling the effects of the war in Afghanistan — a conflict that has lasted a generation — “Carrie was a kind of synecdoche for a rattled America,” James Poniewozik wrote in his review for The New York Times. “She both fought the shadow war for us and felt it,” he added. Now, in its eighth season, “Homeland” puts Carrie back in Afghanistan after months of Russian confinement. With the resurfacing of some Season 1 characters, the season places emphasis on Carrie and Saul’s relationship over the years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: 6 Children and Mother Die in Mississippi Fire, Officials Say
description: “He was going to lead them outside, and when he got to the door and outside, the children were not with him,” the fire chief said of the children’s father.
content: A fire that ripped through a Mississippi home early on Saturday killed a mother and her six children despite the father’s efforts to get them out safely, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Katie Glueck
title: Biden Slashes Into Buttigieg: ‘This Guy’s Not a Barack Obama!’
description: The former vice president and his campaign, under pressure after his poor performance in Iowa, mounted unusually personal attacks on Mr. Buttigieg ahead of the New Hampshire primary.
content: DOVER, N.H. — Tensions in the Democratic presidential primary reached new heights on Saturday as former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and former Mayor Pete Buttigieg clashed over experience in their most pointed confrontation to date, while Senator Bernie Sanders lashed both Mr. Buttigieg and another opponent, Michael R. Bloomberg, on the final weekend before the New Hampshire primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: The Lonely End to One Gray Wolf’s 8,700-Mile Search for a Mate
description: Wildlife officials are investigating the death of OR-54, a female wolf whose carcass was found in Northern California.
content: It had been weeks since biologists at the California Department of Fish and Wildlife were able to track the gray wolf’s movements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Pelosi Clashes With Facebook and Twitter Over Video Posted by Trump
description: The video was edited to appear as if Speaker Nancy Pelosi were ripping a copy of President Trump’s State of the Union address while he honored a Tuskegee airman and military families.
content: Facebook and Twitter have rejected a request by Speaker Nancy Pelosi to remove a video posted by President Trump that was edited to make it appear as though she were ripping a copy of his State of the Union address as he honored a Tuskegee airman and other guests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The Fight to Win New Hampshire
description: A heated Democratic debate on Friday set the stage for a fierce day on the campaign trail in New Hampshire on Saturday.
content: A heated Democratic debate on Friday set the stage for a fierce day on the campaign trail in New Hampshire on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Williams
title: All the Presidents Penned
description: In “Author in Chief,” Craig Fehrman examines the books that American presidents have written before and after they were in office.
content: Announce a political campaign, write a book. This two-step is a national pastime. In “Author in Chief,” Craig Fehrman dives deeper into the books that have been written by presidents, before or after they were in office, including Thomas Jefferson’s “Notes on the State of Virginia” and Ronald Reagan’s little-remembered 1965 autobiography “Where’s the Rest of Me?” Fehrman calls John Adams’ unpublished autobiography the first example of a president trying to write “his own legacy,” in a manuscript that was “extraordinarily personal and pathologically petty.” Barack Obama published his memoir “Dreams From My Father” well before he became president. “He mentioned he was torn between writing a novel or going into politics,” one editor remembers of Obama. “I encouraged him to write a novel.” Below, Fehrman talks about Abraham Lincoln as a best-selling author, the minor historical characters who captured his attention and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah Engel Bromwich, Jessica Testa and Vanessa Friedman
title: What Happened on the 2020 Oscars Red Carpet
description: Did you miss the preshow? We have you covered.
content: Ah, the Oscars red carpet. The ne plus ultra of awards season carpets. The most formal, most glamorous, most ogled, analyzed, criticized and branded carpet of them all. The one that attracts the most eyeballs and thus has the most money riding on it in terms of marketing budgets and contract riders that say this celebrity has to wear that designer because they have a formal brand ambassador relationship with the company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Robert Conrad, Two-Fisted TV Star of ‘Wild Wild West,’ Dies at 84
description: Mr. Conrad, known for tough guy roles, played a secret agent in a mid-1960s television series that transplanted James Bond-style plots into an Old West setting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins, Elisha Brown and Katie Van Syckle
title: Gunman Storms N.Y.P.D. Precinct After Firing at Police Van, Wounding 2
description: The police commissioner called the Bronx rampage an “assassination attempt,” and a backlash grew over anti-police protests.
content: He first shot at two police officers in a van after having asked them for directions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Freeman
title: Who’s Really Shredding Standards on Capitol Hill?
description: Naming the alleged whistle-blower is much worse than tearing up a speech.
content: Last week, the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, said a lot without speaking a word. At the close of President Trump’s State of the Union address, she calmly, deliberately and now famously tore her copy in two and tossed it down with a shrug, declaring her disdain for its contents with aplomb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Freeman
title: Who’s Really Shredding Standards on Capitol Hill?

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Arctic Dining: Think Frozen Sashimi, With a Side of Reindeer Blood
description: Fishermen and reindeer herders in northern Siberia have long snacked on raw, frozen fish and meat. Shaved thin and often dipped in sauce, the dish is one of Russia’s hidden delicacies.
content: YAR-SALE, Russia — The tundra at dusk looks like the open ocean, waves of shades of blue, gray and white.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: Giannis Antetokounmpo Is Unbothered
description: A dozen deadline trades threw the N.B.A. into disarray, but Giannis and the Milwaukee Bucks believe they are still the team to beat.
content: Want more basketball in your inbox? Sign up for Marc Stein’s weekly N.B.A. newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith, Kevin Draper and Tariq Panja
title: The Long Search to Fill Soccer’s Biggest, Toughest Job
description: Why did it take the Premier League more than a year to hire a chief executive? The answer might lie in who was given a say, and in a growing gap between the rich and the even richer.
content: LONDON — There should be no more attractive job in the sports business than being chief executive of the Premier League. England’s top division, after all, is not just a soccer phenomenon, but a cultural one, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Swiss Vote to Penalize Public Homophobia
description: Switzerland had no laws that specifically protected lesbians, gay men and bisexual people from discrimination. Opponents argued that changes would stifle freedom of expression.
content: Swiss voters agreed on Sunday to penalize public homophobia, greenlighting an amendment to an antidiscrimination law that had not provided protection for lesbians, gay men and bisexual people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Muktita Suhartono and Damien Cave
title: ‘Do Not Make Any Loud Noises’: A Thai Soldier’s 18-Hour Shooting Rampage
description: The authorities said the mass shooting, a rarity in the country, started over a real estate dispute and ended with at least 29 people dead and 58 injured.
content: KORAT, Thailand — The authorities killed the gunman near the cold storage refrigerators of the Foodland supermarket in the mall he terrorized during Thailand’s deadliest mass shooting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin
title: Her Grandmother Got the Coronavirus. Then So Did the Whole Family.
description: “What kind of government is this?’ asks a family of three generations sickened by the new virus and desperate for care in Wuhan, the Chinese city at the center of the outbreak.
content: WUHAN, China — Bella Zhang hung an intravenous drip on a spindly tree branch and slumped down on a large stone planter outside the crowded hospital. Her mother and brother sat wearily beside her, their shoulders sagging, both also hooked up to their own drips.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Tom Ford’s ‘Very L.A.’ Show
description: The designer’s show during New York Fashion Week took place in Los Angeles. Jennifer Lopez, Lil Nas X and Tracee Ellis Ross all made the velvet-banquette scene.
content: LOS ANGELES — Is celebrity a status or an incurable cultural condition? The question came to mind when, on the Friday before the national holiday that is the Oscars, Tom Ford held his 2020 show in Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 9, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Feb. 9, 2020.
content: An article last Sunday about the Everglades in Florida misspelled the name of a river that was straightened by the Army Corps of Engineers. It is the Kissimmee River, not Kissimee.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Lauren Escobar, Alex Slater
description: The bride, a clinical pharmacist, and the groom, the director of baseball operations for the L.A. Dodgers, were married in San Diego.
content: Lauren Michelle Escobar and Alex Woo Slater were married Feb. 8 at Darlington House, an events space in San Diego. The Rev. Mark R. Earl, an American Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Zoe Birnbaum, James Frankel
description: He proposed while fellow alumni from the Colgate 13, an all-male college a cappella group he once belonged to, sang backup.
content: Dr. Zoe Danielle Birnbaum and James Matthew Frankel are to be married Feb. 9 by Rabbi Jeffrey Sirkman at Tappan Hill Mansion in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: The Knicks Are Trying Something New: A Rebrand
description: The Knicks have brought in Steve Stoute, a longtime music executive who heads an ad agency, to change how fans — and N.B.A. free agents — perceive the team.
content: “The New York Knicks are the premier global brand in basketball, period,” Steve Stoute, a music executive and the founder of the ad agency Translation, declared recently over breakfast.

author: By The Learning Network
title: The Winners of Our First-Ever Review Contest for Middle Schoolers
description: We invited students ages 10-14 to review a piece of culture, art or technology of their choice. Here are the three winning essays, as well as runners-up and honorable mentions.
content: We’ve been running a Student Review Contest for teenagers for five years now. But this school year, we added a category just for middle school students, ages 10-14.

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Justice Dept. Reviewing Information From Giuliani on the Bidens, Graham Says
description: Senator Lindsey Graham warned that the information should be viewed skeptically. “Russia is playing us all like a fiddle,” he said.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has begun receiving information obtained by Rudolph W. Giuliani, President Trump’s personal lawyer, from Ukraine about former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his son, Senator Lindsey Graham said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Carpenter
title: 3,500 Women, 6 Continents and a Year of Riding High
description: Through sleet and monsoons, cities and villages, the Women Riders World Relay has inspired motorcyclists “to show themselves and each other what they are capable of.”
content: The night Hayley Bell threw a leg over her KTM motorcycle and pointed the front tire toward Scotland, it was pitch black and sleeting — exactly the sort of miserable weather most bikers would avoid. But she isn’t like most bikers. Ms. Bell, a 28-year-old from Northern England, was on a mission.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Our favorite looks from the 2020 Academy Awards red carpet.
content: Our favorite looks from the 2020 Academy Awards red carpet.

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Highlights From Solar Orbiter’s Launch on Mission to See Sun’s Top and Bottom
description: Over the next decade, the joint NASA-European Space Agency spacecraft will make close observations of the sun.
content: A rocket carrying Solar Orbiter, a probe that will take pictures of the top and bottom of the sun, launched Saturday night. The Atlas 5 rocket launched on time, just as the final Oscar statues were being handed out for the 2020 Academy Awards. It illuminated the night sky over Florida’s Atlantic coast as it headed away from Earth to place thespacecraft into an orbit around the sun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: ‘Birds of Prey’ Stumbles at the Box Office
description: The DC Comics spinoff led ticket sales this weekend, but its estimated $33.3 million debut is disappointing.
content: Topping the box office, “Birds of Prey (and the Fantabulous Emancipation of One Harley Quinn)” still fell far below projections. Analysts had expected the film’s domestic opening to reach around $50 million; instead it brought in $33.3 million.

title: Review: A Violinist Connects the Dots From Bach to the Present

content: For his recital at the 92nd Street Y on Friday, the young violinist Alexi Kenney engaged in something like that pointless but nonetheless fun thought experiment: Which people, living or dead, would you invite to a dinner party?

title: Deaths in China Surpass Toll From SARS
description: More than 900 people have died from the new virus in China. The 2002-3 epidemic, which also began in the country, killed 774 people worldwide.
content: The coronavirus death toll in China has risen to 908, surpassing the toll from the SARS epidemic of 2002-3, according to official data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling
title: ‘Parasite’ Makes Oscar History With Best Picture Win
description: The South Korean film was the first foreign-language movie to win the top award. It also won best director, best international film and best original screenplay.
content: LOS ANGELES — A foreign-language film finally conquered the Oscars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers and Karen Zraick
title: Coronavirus Epidemic Reaches Bleak Milestone, Exceeding SARS Toll
description: This outbreak has killed more people, and more quickly, than a previous epidemic.
content: BEIJING — The coronavirus epidemic in China surpassed a grim milestone on Sunday with a death toll that exceeds that of the SARS outbreak 17 years ago, a development that coincided with news that World Health Organization experts might soon be in the country to help stanch the crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Streitfeld
title: In Amazon’s Bookstore, No Second Chances for the Third Reich
description: The retailer once said it would sell “the good, the bad and the ugly.” Now it has banished objectionable volumes — and agreed to erasing the swastikas from a photo book about a Nazi takeover.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Amazon is quietly canceling its Nazis.

title: As Deaths Mount, China Tries to Speed Up Coronavirus Testing
description: China is racing to screen ever more patients in Hubei Province, acknowledging that delays in diagnosing the virus are a major obstacle to controlling the epidemic.
content: Dr. Zhang Xiaochun, who works in a hospital in Wuhan, was in dismay. Her patient had been running a fever for nine days, and a CT scan showed signs of pneumonia — symptoms of the new coronavirus sweeping across the central Chinese city.

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Suitable for Moviemaking
description: Bruce Haight helps us get the picture.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — How many times has this happened to you? You wake up on a Monday morning, open your newspaper or your crossword app and suddenly, you are transported to a film set. Everyone is busy working on the film, and you are standing in the middle, not sure how you got there, or even how to make a contribution. Talk about the ultimate stress dream.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Change How We Elect the President?
description: Readers offer alternative ways of determining electoral votes and a defense of the current Electoral College system.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: Mirella Freni, Matchless Italian Prima Donna, Dies at 84
description: Ms. Freni was acclaimed for her exquisite singing in lighter lyric roles. In midcareer she also dared to explore weightier ones.
content: Mirella Freni, an exemplary Italian prima donna for nearly 50 years, whose voice was ideally suited to lighter lyric roles but maintained its bloom even as she took on weightier, more dramatic repertory in midcareer, died on Sunday at her home in Modena, in north-central Italy. She was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Suitable for Moviemaking
description: Bruce Haight helps us get the picture.

author: By Adam Satariano
title: He Combs the Web for Russian Bots. That Makes Him a Target.
description: Ben Nimmo helped pioneer disinformation investigations. His work is now more urgent as misleading internet tactics spread.
content: HADDINGTON, Scotland — In August 2017, Ben Nimmo was declared dead by 13,000 Russian bots on Twitter.

author: By Nathaniel Popper
title: Ransomware Attacks Grow, Crippling Cities and Businesses
description: Hackers are locking people out of their networks and demanding big payments to get back in. New data shows just how common and damaging the attacks have become.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — New Orleans’s city government crippled. A maritime cargo facility temporarily closed. Hospitals forced to turn away patients. Small businesses shuttered.

author: By Andrew Das
title: ‘It’s Cutthroat’: U.S. Women Beat Canada, but Tougher Battle Looms
description: As the United States women’s national soccer team prepares for the Tokyo Olympics, its players are waging daily battles for a limited number of roster spots.
content: CARSON, Calif. — A great example of the relentless competition for roster spots on the United States women’s soccer team might have been a short video clip that popped up on social media on Wednesday.
